I had such high hopes for this game. I love the Overcooked! series, and I played both original games to completion. They were so much fun that when I saw this game on the store page, I bought it immediately. 

Unfortunately, while the game itself keeps the magic of the originals and even adds some really fun new worlds and content, the connectivity issues make this game absolutely unplayable. My friends and I were disconnecting constantly, and one of the worlds just straight up would not work. After experiencing these issues, I browsed the reviews and forums, and this is a very common issue and has been a problem since release. It certainly seems like Team17 has no plans to fix this game and its server issues.

While there is lots of fun to be had, I would recommend just buying the two original games and skipping this one; it's more trouble than it's worth.

However, what makes this game truly shine is the chaotic fun it delivers when you play with friends. It's not just about cooking; it's about laughter, frustration, and the challenge of working together seamlessly. Your friendships will be put to the test, and it's a brilliant way to see just how well you and your buddies can coordinate under the pressure of a busy kitchen. Overcooked! It's easily the best deal if you want the full Overcooked experience, as it includes a remaster of both Overcooked 1 & 2, all extra DLCs plus new ones, fully integrated online with new features such as voice chat, and even has enhanced 4K graphics with 60 FPS in it, which is even better than Overcooked! 2 graphics. The original Overcooked games weren't too replayable, but this one definitely is as it has SO much content in it. It has ALL overcooked content and costs less than buying both overcooked 1 and 2 and is easily the best option if you're looking to buy all there is to overcooked. It's a great and amazingly fun experience, and I cannot stress enough how much of a great time I had playing this game with my family. 10/10 for me, I haven't played a game this fun in a long time, and in my opinion, it's one of the best options out there if you're looking to buy a party game. I have honestly never played a game that infuriated me more than this game.

I got this game to play with two other friends, and coming from a game called PlateUp, I thought that with a similar premise, we were going to have a lot of fun. It initially did start off as a fun, challenging game. However, over the course of the game, that challenged turned into absurd difficulty and it started getting ridiculous.

Some of the levels the game throws at you are really difficult to wrap around, but imagine trying to get multiple people to understand it and figure out how to optimally work with each other. We had to take several attempts to barely understand the levels, combine it with some minor bugs in this game, and other minor details, the game knows how to infuriate you. And I hate how this is the default difficulty of the game. The fact that the game has ways to make it easier through "Assist Settings" is condescending and makes you feel like you are not good enough for the game.

Getting 3 stars on a level honestly isn't possible unless you and your friends completely sweat with the dashes and get good RNG with the recipes. It was through this that we got a few close calls to 3 stars, but only falling a few points short. But the game deliberately times you to where if you don't get it within the second, the customer gets impatient and fails you. 

I know PlateUp has some finnicky controls, but it is much worse in this game. Sometimes whenever I place an ingredient in a pot or trying to pick up a pot/pan before the meat burns, the game oftentimes misunderstood where I was facing and decides to place what I'm holding on the completely wrong tile, or it picks up an item I'm not even looking at. It's almost as if the developers didn't do enough playtesting to iron out these seemingly minor issues that can make or break an attempt.

Also, don't bother playing this on singleplayer. On singleplayer, you have to control two people and it is difficult to manage, especially if you are playing with a controller. If you ever choose to play this game, at least get it with a friend so it becomes more bearable. Get a good friend, so that when the both of you get upset trying to do some of the levels, you can forget it.

The plot is cheesy, but I can overlook it. I like the look of the game, it's nice and refreshing. The soundtrack is pretty nice. But that's all the positives that I can say about this game. Unless you're willing to sweat or you can hold your rage, don't buy this game.

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] Overcooked! All You Can Eat is a complete edition consisting of both Overcooked! games, all DLC, & some additional stages to entice owners of the previous titles.  The games still have that goofy charm to them with their silly plot & irreverent stages.  The controls are tight & fluid, leaving little room for error outside of human control.  The variety of stages & dishes is still just as nice as ever, with different mechanics unique to each stage.  The soundtrack is equally as charming, with the overworld theme being the easiest to stick in one's memory.  Finally, the co-op is just as fun as ever, making the stages both easier to complete & more chaotic to run about, as well as increasing the star required score due to the number of chefs running about.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] Overcooked! 1 feels slightly out of place, the lack of a throw food option making the game feel a bit slower.  Where the stages are varied, some can be quite annoying due to the individual level features, such as ice physics in the ice world.  The largest con for fans of the series would be the game's status.  As a complete edition of both titles, this is not a bundle, meaning players who already own both games will already have about 90% of this in their collection already.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] This is actually an easier list than the original titles this was based off of.  The removal of the heavier grind achievements have been replaced with ones requiring multiple chefs to be specific chefs.  This needs to be done online, or locally using a controller & keyboard/second controller.  There really isn't too much difficulty here, other than completing the main campaigns if one finds them difficult.  One doesn't even need to finish a majority of the DLC to clear the list either.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Overcooked! All You Can Eat is a fun bundle of two fast paced, enjoyable games with some extra DLC added for those who want more.  It's colorful style & frenetic gameplay creates a wonderful experience, be it solo, couch co-op, or online.  Though owners of the titles would be much better off waiting for a sale, newcomers should jump on this first rather than start with the earlier games.  A solid recommendation for anyone interested.

Got this game a while ago and I've been really trying my best to get into it. Let me preface this by saying that I work actual food service. I find cooking to be quite enjoyable and a little bit of micromanagement, especially in a real world setting, is absolutely no problem to me at all. When I played this game for the first time, my experience was a bit akward and uncomfortable, much like how you'd feel at your first day in a real job. This feeling didn't go away however. I initially wrote it off as just me being bad, however the more patient I try to be with this game, the more frustrated I get, and I think I should get my views on this game out just to validate the feelings of those in the same predicament as me, since I really didn't see anybody acknowledging this in the reviews. Maybe this is just me and my play style, but this game is FAR too gimmicky for me to play. The base gameplay which consists of prepping food and serving it has virtually no depth to it, making a good 90% of this game pointless, impractical, micromanagement due to all the pointless and nonsensical gimmicks in the game. If there's anything I know from my experiences with games, it's that difficulty is no substitute for gameplay, and this game is practically the reason I believe that. Sometimes you'll be prepping food and the entire kitchen starts moving away from you (WTF??!) or the kitchen will have an infestation of super rats that can locate and acquire food as soon as it's dropped. My personal favorite is that level where people are just casually walking through the kitchen. That kind of stupidity and spatial unawareness makes me absolutely livid. If somebody walked through the kitchen at work we'd literally just kick them the fuck out. So why the hell should I take that shit in a game? Every level there's a dumber, more bizarre obstacle that holds dominion over the kitchen that you just happen to be working in. I understand that this is a video game, but this is a game about cooking. Why the hell am I forced to play in these levels that are were so obviously not designed to be cooked in? The level choices are creative, but frustrating and practically designed against you, which I have to hold against the game since it's just so unrealistic for a food service environment. There's a way to make your game difficult without making it this ridiculously frustrating. Take a game like Touhou 6 or Crash Bandicoot for example. Those levels are clearly designed for you to play them, and the difficulty is based on skill, where as in Overcooked it's more about management. You can't just make a game super overwhelming and substitute that in for difficulty. I'm a bit of a perfectionist so I found it hard to even get started on most levels let alone get a good flow going, and that's basically why I'm writing this review. In my opinion, it feels like the player has very little control over the game, and instead of actually introducing skills that let players thrive in that environment, the game focuses more on just putting the player somewhere and forcing them to just deal with it. If I wanted to deal with annoying customers, I'd go back to work and actually get paid for it. This game is really cute and has a lot of accessibility features, but it feels like you're trying to do a job while a group of mentally disabled children running amok and wreaking havoc on your workspace. To give you a better example, this game is like a Mario game where all the levels are water levels, and instead of making them harder as they went on they just added ridiculous spams of enemies. Cute game, not worth the stress at all imo. This is the only game where I can be bored of the gameplay while still stressing out about the levels. Not fun for me, 6/10.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Will preface by saying I love this franchise, and have bought each game and DLC prior on both PS4 and Steam. So, bias laid bare, to the review:

If you've never played Overcooked before, this is an incredible deal at $40 for all the content. Over 200 levels, with couch or online co-op for up to 4 players, as well as crossplay with other platforms. It's quite fun for both casual party play, and the more hardcore competitive end has a scene as well. overcooked.greeny.dev tracks high scores, and the Overcooked League Discord hosts no-stakes tournaments to test your skill against other teams in a somewhat live sense.

If you HAVE played every Overcooked game and DLC prior to this, it may be hard to justify the price tag. What you add is online play for OC1 levels, more chefs to play as, 7 brand new levels, somewhat better load times, and having everything in one package. I got a 15% dicount for owning all prior content. While not much, with how much play time I've gotten out of the series thus far, I was happy to support the dev more. So use your best judgement if the moderate convenience improvement is worth it to you.

There ARE currently some bugs that need working out with connectivity, though my personal experience hasn't been a dealbreaker. Hopefully these will be fixed in the future.

Another issue I hear of is bad controller support. I personally run 8bitdo with my PS4 controller emulated as a 360 controller, and have no issues with that. I'd do some research on it depending on your setup.

Overall, while there's some launch issues, I still highly recommend this game.

Real talk. The game is Overcooked 1 and 2 with all the DLC repackaged. Some visual optimizations have been done but it's not all that different of an experience from the other games. If you already own the other two, it's likely not worth the purchase. The ONLY reason I'm purchasing this game is because of the inclusion of cross-platform multiplayer: I have a niche case where netplay options like Steam Remote Play Together and Parsec aren't viable. In my view, there isn't anything else here at launch that would convince me to buy.

Don't get me wrong, it's a good game. It doesn't give much value beyond the original games, but if you haven't played Overcooked before, this is a fantastic bundle. And who knows: maybe the free content promised later this year might make up for the lack of new content... I'm not crossing my fingers for that, but we shall see.
